thread.title: Catalan independence bid in TATTERS after Spanish court shuns ‘Scotland-style’ vote
thread.title_full: Catalan independence bid in TATTERS after Spanish court shuns ‘Scotland-style’ vote

title: Catalan independence bid in TATTERS after Spanish court shuns ‘Scotland-style’ vote
text:
Catalan independence bid in TATTERS after Spanish court shuns ‘Scotland-style’ vote Catalan independence bid in TATTERS after Spanish court shuns ‘Scotland-style’ vote PLANS for an independence referendum by Catalonia’s regional parliament has been quashed by Spain’s Constitutional Court despite increasing calls for the region to become self-governing. PUBLISHED: 00:10,  20, Wed, Feb 15, 2017 GETTY Catalonia's bid for independence was dealt a fresh blow after the referendum vote was blocked 
The Madrid-based Constitutional Court claimed the independence bid was “unconstitutional”, cancelling the resolution outright. 
The decision is likely to fuel tensions between the Spanish and Catalan governments, with relations already strained after the region’s former president, Artur Mas, stood trial last week charged with civil disobedience and misconduct after his attempts to push an independence vote through. Related articles Catalonia to hold independence referendum in Brussels charm offensive 
The Catalan parliament, which has a majority of separatist lawmakers, adopted the resolution in October last year amid plans to hold a referendum in September. 
However, the Spanish Constitutional Court suspended the resolution in December and cancelled it today, leaving independence hopes in tatters. 
Mr Mas had previously tried to hold a similar referendum which was also banned, and the former Catalan president countered by calling a symbolic, non-binding independence vote, which was also stopped by the court. GETTY Former president Artur Mas (2nd L) alongside his successor Carles Puigdemont (C) in court last week 
Despite the court’s block Mr Mas went ahead with the symbolic vote anyway in November 2014, with more than 80 per cent of the 2.3 million voters opting for independence - although only a small proportion of the 6.3 million eligible voters took part. 
Mr Mas’ move resulted in the charges he is now on trial for, with prosecutors pushing for the former president to be banned from public office for 10 years if he is found guilty. How safe is your 2017 summer holiday Tue, February 14, 2017
